Roof slope is the vertical rise in
inches for every horizontal distance
of twelve inches (called the "run"). It
is expressed as rise:run or, in this
example 6:12.
Note: On a drawing this slope
might also be represented as:

6
or
2

visual_elements.description: A table titled 'Structure' and 'Max. height to roof peak' listing different dwelling types and their maximum allowed roof peak heights.
A diagram illustrating how to determine the slope of a roof, showing a cross-section of a roof with a horizontal 'run' of 12 inches and a vertical 'rise' of 6 inches.

A series of five house silhouettes with different roof slopes (12:14, 12:12, 12:10, 12:6, 12:3) demonstrating 'Comparison of roof slopes'. Two height limits are indicated: 33' for the first two houses and 30' for the last three, with a horizontal line representing 'Height measured to top of roof material'.

additional_notes: Page number '46' is printed at the bottom left.

The text 'Height allowances enable a variety of architectural styles while preserving the residential scale of our neighborhoods as well as the privacy and natural light available to each lot.' is presented in a shaded box on the left side of the page.
